medium_description_en: Diagnoses appendicitis with lab values and clinical findings, especially for Asian populations.
short_description_en: Diagnoses appendicitis with lab values and clinical findings.

seo.meta_description_en: The RIPASA Score for Acute Appendicitis diagnoses appendicitis with lab values and clinical findings, specifically for Asian populations.
seo.keywords_en: ripasa, ripasa score, acute appy, acute appendicitis, appendicitis, asian appendicitis

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• RIPASA is a scoring system for diagnosing appendicitis.
    • Similar to the Alvarado Score, it typically provides a quantitive value for a clinician's clinical gestalt of appendicitis.
  • It is very accurate for the diagnosis of appendicitis when above a point threshold - typically above 7.5 points.

Points to keep in mind:

  • It has been most widely studied in Asian populations (Singapore, India) and less so in Western populations.
  • Because it was developed in Singapore which has a large number of foreign nationals, the “Foreign national registration identity card” was included in the score as it was found to have some predictive capacity. This is harder to apply to other populations.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Negative appendectomies were relatively common in the RIPASA study cohorts, suggesting that use of the score might have reduced unnecessary surgeries while missing few with appendicitis.

next_steps.advice_en: In settings where advanced imaging is used more liberally, the performance of the RIPASA Score is unclear, and no study has yet assessed its impact when applied clinically.
next_steps.management_en: We are unaware of validated management algorithms using the RIPASA Score.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: The RIPASA Score integrates and thus requires a number of laboratory test results and historical features, and while accuracy is high in initial studies, a larger more rigorous validation and/or implementation study would be very useful.

about.more_info_en: The cutoff value of 7.5 points was 98% sensitive and 81% specific for diagnosis of appendicitis.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Chong CF, Adi MI, Thien A, Suyoi A, Mackie AJ, Tin AS, Tripathi S, Jaman NH, Tan KK, Kok KY, Mathew VV, Paw O, Chua HB, Yapp SK. Development of the RIPASA score: a new appendicitis scoring system for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Singapore Med J. 2010 Mar;51(3):220-5.

Other References.text: Chong CF, Thien A, Mackie AJ, Tin AS, Tripathi S, Ahmad MA, Tan LT, Ang SH, Telisinghe PU. Comparison of RIPASA and Alvarado scores for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Singapore Med J. 2011 May;52(5):340-5.

Validation.text: Butt MQ, Chatha SS, Ghumman AQ, Farooq M. RIPASA score: a new diagnostic score for diagnosis of acute appendicitis. J Coll Physicians Surg Pak. 2014 Dec;24(12):894-7. doi: 12.2014/JCPSP.894897.

creator_info.about_en: William Chong, MD, MBBS, BSc, is a cardiothoracic surgeon at RIPAS Hospital in Bandar Seri Begawan in Brunei. He is an active researcher in his field as well as in general surgery.
